_meanings:
{2} a match-maker or
{#Gawaka#} (that word consisting of three
syllables.)

{1} three strings 
suspended to either end of a pole for
carrying burdens.

the three kinds of collyrium;
{%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#kAlAMjana, rasAMjana#}, and {#puzpAMjana#}.

epithets of the river.
Ganges (flowing through the three
worlds).

an army consisting
of horses, elephants and chariots.

three years old. 

({#bdaM#}) three years taken collectively.

{1} performed
or produced in three days.

{4} a sacrifice lasting for ten
nights.

the chief three duties of a Brāhmaṇa
{%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} sacrifice, study of the Vedas,
and making gifts or charity.

one who engages in these three
duties (as a Brāhmaṇa).

{1} the
three times; the past, the 
present, and the future, or 
morning, noon and evening.

{2} the three
tenses (the past, present, and future)
of a verb.

<ab>N.</ab> of a mountain
in Ceylon on the top of which was
situated Laṅkā, the capital of 
Rāvaṇa; <ls>Śi. 2. 5.</ls>

an
aggregate of the three objects of
worldly existence; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#DarBa, arTa#} and
{#kAma; na bADataM'sya trigaRaH parasparaM#}  
<ls>Ki. 1. 11</ls>; see {#trivarga#} below.

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a country, also called
{#jalaMDara#}, in the north-west of India.

{2}
the people or rulers of that country.

{3} containing
the three Guṇas {#satva, rajasa#} and {#tamas#}

the three worlds, (1)
the heaven, the atmosphere, and the
earth; or (2) the heaven, the earth,
and the lower world.

<ab>N.</ab> of a female
demon, one of the Rākṣasa 
attendants kept by Rāvaṇa to
watch over Sītā, when she was
retained as a captive in the
Aśoka-vanikā. She acted very
kindly towards Sītā and induced
her companions to do the same

the sine of three signs or 90°,
a radius.

a part of the Adhvaryu
sacrifice or Yajurveda, or one who
performs a vow connected therewith
(according to <ls>Kull.</ls> on <ls>Ms. 3. 185</ls>).

a wife (‘thrice married’; it
being supposed that a girl belongs
to {%Soma%}, {%Gandharva%} and {%Agni%}
before she obtains a human 
husband).

{1} the
three staves of a {%Saṃnyāsin%} (who
has resigned the world) tied 
together so as to form one.

{2} the
triple subjection of thought. word,
and deed.

the state of a
religious ascetic.

{1} 
areligious mendicant or {%Saṃnyāsin%} who
has renounced all worldly 
attachments, and who carries three long
staves tied together so as to form
one in his right hand.

vitiation or 
derangement of the three humours of
the body, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#vAta, pitta#} and {#vaPa#}.

{1} the hand with three fingers
stretched out or erect.

{2} the 
forehead marked naturally with three
horizontal lines.

{1} the three paths taken
collectively, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} the sky, 
atmosphere, and the earth, or the sky,
earth and the lower world.

{2}
a place where three reads meet.

one
who walks thrice round a sacred
fire.

{1} intersection of a prolonged side
and perpendicular (in a 
quadrangular figure).

{2} the figure formed
by such intersection.

{2} one who learns a thing
after three repetitions.

{1} an epithet of Viṣṇu in
his dwarf incarnation.

a mark on the
forehead consisting of three lines
made with cowdung ashes.

<ab>N.</ab> of a demon or 
demons presiding over these cities.

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a place near 
Jabbalpura, formerly capital of the kings
of Cedi.

{1} having the length of three
men.

the three ancestors, father,
grand-father, and great-grand-father.

{1} belonging to, or extending over,
three generations of men.

the
three myrobalans taken collectively,
(<ab>Mar.</ab> {#hiraqA, behaqA#} and {#AMvaLakAWI#}).

{1} the
three folds or wrinkles of skin above
the navel of a woman (regarded as
a mark of beauty);  
{#kzAmodaroparilasattrivalIlatAnAM#} <ls>Bh. 1. 93</ls>, <ls n="Bh. 1.">81</ls>; <ab>cf.</ab>  
<ls>Ku. 1. 39.</ls>

a kind of fighting
with swords.

three signs of
the zodiac, or ninety degrees.

having the three sages {#pARini#}, 
{#kAtyAyana#} and {#pataMjali#}; {#trimuni vyAkaraRam#}.

{1} the united form of Brahmā,
Viṣṇu, and Maheśa, the Hindu
triad; <ls>Ku. 2. 4.</ls>

a law-suit (in which
a person engages from anger, 
covetousness, or infatuation).

a festival
lasting for three nights.

having three
genders, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} an adjective.

an
inhabitant of the three worlds.

‘lord of the
three worlds’ an epithet of

the
three metals:--gold, silver, and
copper.

{1} the three objects
of worldly existence, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#Darma, arTa#},
and {#kAma#}; <ls>Ku. 5. 38.</ls>

{2} the three
states of loss, stability, and 
increase; {#kzayaH sTAnaM ca vfdDiSca trivargo#}
{#nItivedinAM#} <ls>Ak.</ls>

{3} the three qualities
of nature, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#sattva, rajas#}, and {#tamas#}.

the first three of
the four castes of Hindus taken
collectively.

Viṣṇu in his fifth or
dwarf incarnation.

a 
Brāhmaṇa versed in the three Vedas.

a plant possessing
valuable purgative properties.

combining three things, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} earth,
water, and fire.

the
place near Prayāga where the
Ganges joins the Yamunā and 
receives under ground the Sarasvatī.

a Brāhmaṇa versed in the
three Vedas.

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a
celebrated king of the Solar race,
king of Ayodhyā and father of 
Hariśchandra. [He was a wise, pious, and
just king, but his chief fault was that
he loved his person to an inordinate 
degree. Desiring to celebrate a sacrifice by
virtue of which he could go up to heaven
in his mortal body, he requested his
family-priest Vasiṣṭha to officiate for
him; but being refused he next 
requested his hundred sons who also rejected
his absurd proposal. He, therefore,
called them cowardly and impotent, and
was, in return for these insults, cursed
and degraded by them to be a Chāṇḍāla. 

While he was in this wretched 
condition, Viśvāmitra, whose family Triśaṅku
had in times of famine laid under deep
obligations, undertook to celebrate the
sacrifice, and invited all the gods to be
present. They, however, declined;
whereupon the enraged Viśvāmitra by
his own power lifted up Triśaṅku to the
skies with his cherished mortal body.
He began to soar higher and higher till
his head struck against the vault of the
heaven, when he was hurled down 
headforemost by Indra and the other gods.
The mighty Viśvāmitra, however, 
arrested him in his downward course, saying
‘Stay Triśaṅku’, and the unfortunate
monarch remained suspended with his
head towards the earth as a constellation
in the southern hemisphere. Hence the
well-known proverb; {#triSaMkurivAMtarA#} 
{#tizWa#} <ls>Ś. 2</ls>].

a
house with three halls or chambers.

{2} a crown or
crest (with three points).
{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a demon killed by Rāma.

the three periods of the
day, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} dawn, noon, and sunset.

at the time of the three
Saṃdhyās.

(in geom.) having three equal
sides, equilateral.

the three sacred places,
{#kASI, prayAga#}, and {#gayA#}.
